Message.Msg: Eom

I seriously doubt $19 to $20. The problem is that there won't be any other bidders. So the question that Silverlake needs to decide is what's the chance of it being a no vote. So I bet they are talking with Southwestern to see if they can get them to agree to vote yes if they raise the bid. It seems as though most "experts", which I'm not, seem to thing $15 would have been fair. So I would think if they would up it to at least $15 then they would seal enough yes votes for it to be a done deal. But I believe if it doesn't go higher, that there is a good chance there is a no vote.
So if you are a long term investor, would it matter if it goes to $9? Because at $9 and all that cash someone else is eventually going to scoop this up for more than $9.

http://blogs.wsj.com/source/2013/02/08/two-options-for-michael-dell/?mod=yahoo_hs Quote from WSJ "The first is to milk the cow. Dell’s private equity partners can generate a 22% annualized internal rate of return by doing very little. They can sit idle and reap rich dividends with minimal execution risk over the next few years." With this type of return the company is worth a lot more, raise the offer!

Topic.Title: Southeastern Asset Management - Doesn't like the price

Message.Msg: I'm not sure I follow your logic. First of all M Dell and Silverlake aren't buying this for $13.65 to be nice. They feel they can make a good profit taking it private and selling it later. So are you saying if you are M. Dell and Silverlake, that if you felt that Southeastern and enough other major holders vote no, that they'd rather walk away versus maybe giving another $1 or $2 to secure enough yes votes? Also, if you were M. Dell and Silverlake and you felt there was a chance there could be another bid or at least a shareholder revolt, would you give your absolutely best price? No, it's like buying a house or car. If you can afford a $300 car payment, you would be silly to tell the salesguy from the start you can afford $300. Same thing here, I'm sure they have the ability to raise their bid. Remember there were rumors that they could go up to $15.

Message.Title: Anything under 20 is robbery mike

Message.Msg: Agree

NY Times DealBook released an article at 3:27PM that Southeastern Asset Management will Fight Dell’s Takeover. The time co-incided with the start of the SP spike. The article said: '...Southeastern Asset Management, whose 8.5 percent stake makes it the biggest outside shareholder in Dell, said in a regulatory filing on Friday that it planned to oppose its $24.4 billion sale to its founder and the investment firm Silver Lake. In its filing, Southeastern argues that the management-led buyout is too low and essentially robs shareholders. The asset management firm is threatening to wage a protracted and hostile campaign to kill the deal. “We retain and intend to avail ourselves of all options at our disposal to oppose the proposed transaction, including but not limited to a proxy fight, litigation claims and any available Delaware statutory appraisal rights,” the firm said. Southeastern is not opposed to other moves that would have returned value to shareholders, including borrowing money to pay out a special dividend or a leveraged buyout that would have allowed for limited trading of shares by public investors....'
Doesn't matter.Mike and his band of thieves will use strongarm robbery if they have to.

Message.Title: Michael Dell:
Message.Msg: He is a gangster - a simple bank robber. He is setting a bad precedent for all CEOs with large investments in their own companies. This is all my personal opinion - but none of us should let him get away this theft. Vote "NO".
M. Dells 14% stake does not count in the majority of minority vote.

Message.Title: No point in holding the buyout
Message.Msg: This is a smart decision by Mr Dell. I finally had a chance to look at surface pro. Its basically the xps 12.5 convertible killer. The only advantage xps has is that I believe the ssd drive is upgradable. XPS would've been a killer device and the stock at $20 had the xps been just the display form factor... Sometimes being at the top has its disadvantage.. the lower level product managers are not as competitive. Had I been the CEO, I'd have had my way, not be as good as Mr Dell is. But I guess its more respectable his way. sigh.... There possibly definitely more to being a CEO... but what does it take to build a $500B company? Why not buy a cheaper RT and office? How the heck can I run my Rosetta Stone on the RT device? Pro wins .. No one understands. They just salivate for no reason. Make me the Product Strategy Director if we need more success. Now.

Message.Title: I will vote No. Dell Stock Price will only go up from here.
Message.Msg: I am going to vote No for my 2000 shares. My avg cost was $13.75, why should I sell my shares to bank robber? For those who think it will down to $9 if deal is block, you are totally wrong. If it drops to $9, guess who is the biggest loser? Not me, not you, not Southeastern. It will be that bank robber, Michael Dell who owns 15% of the company. He and his wallstreet robbers will eventually raise the price if we all say no. He knows the value of this company. Otherwise, he will share the pain when price drops to $9.

Let me explain further: Part of what the Board of Directors did do for shareholders was require 2 votes for the deal to go through, both votes had to be successful. 1) M. Dell had to vote in favor with his 14%. No Brainer there. 2) A majority of the Shares MINUS M. Dells stake must vote in favor. 100 - 14 = 86%. 50.1% of the remaining 86% of the shares must vote in favor. That reduces the amount of shares needed to stop this by a bunch. So the 8.5% stake now carries a lot more weight, by itself still not near enough but we have already heard from several of the other large shareholders who said NO WAY. Add my 10k in and we are almost there. :)

Message.Title: Southeastern Asset Management made a mistake
Message.Msg: This management outfit made the mistake of getting too deep in Dell shares, at too high share prices, and now is looking at a loss. That's their problem. It's not Mike Dell's job to ensure that Southeasterrn (or any other investor) makes a profit from buying Dell shares. Mike Dell's job is to manage Dell's business operations, which as evidenced by DELL's revenues and profits , he does very well. By making public their dissatisfaction with the $13.65 buyout price all Southeastern is doing is drawing attention to themselves as an incompetent money management company. I expect that due to this revelation Southeastern will lose some its current and potential future investor clients. To have a loss is one thing, but to make matters worse by publicizing it is stupid.
A month ago DELL stock was 25% less than it is today. Robbers take money away from you, not give you more. Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: Southeastern Asset Management made a mistake

Message.Msg: Mike Dell will be the biggest loser if it drops back to single digit. I think M Dell is in big dilemma now: 1. Deal is blocked, Silver Lake walks, Price goes down to $9 M Dell will lose $4.65 / share ($13.65 - $9) 2. Raise the price to $16 ( $16 - $13.65 = $2.35) M Dell has to raise $2.35 of his buyout offer, which he can easily make it back from this year's cash flow. He knows the value of this company and Southeastern has calculated the valuation for us to clearly understand they are robbing us. Which one will he choose?

Topic.Title: Southeastern Asset Management made a mistake

Message.Msg: Mike Dell will walk away from the $13.65 offer. I expect the original offer his grioup had planned was about $12.50 per share, which was a nice big premium over the $10-$10.50 where DELL had traded much of last year.However, leaks of a pending buoyout sent the shares up near $13. To make the new higher price work I expect Mike Dell and Silverlake had to add a bank lender or two and that is probably when Microsoft agreed to lend some money as well. Regardless of what a few disgruntled stockholders (who originally paid too much for their DELL shares) may want, that does not change the fact that $13.65, $24 billion, is a premium valuation for Dell's current business operations. In all likelihood, if the LBO group walks away now, Wall Street will drop the stock down to trading at about $9 per share. Mike dell and his LBo group can always come back at a later time and take the company private for $12 (or less).

Topic.Title: Southeastern Asset Management made a mistake

Message.Msg: I am waiting for $9 drop to buy a lot more-----Bashfordcapital. How much dell pays you anyway/post. just few cents. HOPE This helps.

Look at WAMU case! so manny shareholders robed ---nothing bussniess as ususal. Rober JP morgan. All share holders crying for justice nothing. Now Dell doing similar thing-----On wall street you rob or get robed---that is the norm

Where were you guys when DELL stock was trading $9 per share not long ago ? If you all think DELL is worth $16, $18, $20 etc.... then you should have been buying as much as you could back at $9. I suggest you now stop crying for having missed this one, and go find another stock where you may make some money. Hope this helps.

basher, do you realize that Michael Dell, the largest shareholder, CANNOT vote his shares on the matter? He will recuse himself. Do you realize that SE, the second largest shareholder, called the deal "disturbing" and "outrageous"? So the largest shareholder can't vote and the second largest shareholder will vote no. This deal is already dead. If you don't realize it now, you will in 45 days. Hope that helps.

For conversation let's say DELL is a pie of 100 shares. Mike has 16 shares, and we will remove those from the pie, making the voting pie 84 shares.Southeastern has 8 shares, which they are threatening to vote against the merger. Add to that a few other large shareholders who comibned have 8 votes. So, worst case scenario 16 of 84 votes (from significant shareowners)will be NO. But let's add a bunch of passionate little amateurs like fluteman or CTG or mrphile who are sitting at home in t-shirt and jeans, sweating their 500 share positions here. But, because they watched some 15 year old Hollywood movie about Wall Street , they think they know how the game is played. For conversation let's add every little fools share count to the mix and call it 25 NO votes out of 84. Understand, the overwehleming majority of shareowners never cast a vote, And, plenty are very pleased to get $13.65 for their shares, becase that's a lot better price than $10, where DELL traded much of last year. Get the picture now? hope this helps.

Topic.Title: My Prediction - Free Fall on earnings

Message.Msg: Disagree. The DELL pps is now based on the LBO price being raised to a price acceptable to major shareholders. Earnings now are irrelevant.

Topic.Title: My Prediction - Free Fall on earnings

Message.Msg: Your post makes sense. Obviously, Mike Dell needs to accellerate the restructurring of his company away from dependence on PC's towards business enterprise products and solutions. That restructurring will take years of time as well as sales of some company assets. Impatient Wall Street wwill not be pleased with short term negative results, which is after all the primary reason he desires to privatize the company. If and when Dell is eventually able to withstand a company restruccturing and gain some significant traction in profitable business lines, a process which will likely take 3 to 5 years, Mike Dell and his LBO team will have certainly earned the right to then profit from their work. Who among us common stockholders is willing to wait 3 to 5 years for higher gains rather than take now the generous premium offer of $13.65 for our shares? Myself and other rsensible stockholders without hesitation say yes to the curret buyout offer. Southeasern , and a few greed yamateur stock pickers, want more now, without assumig the risk or years necessary to reposition the business. They are silly and unreasonable. Hope this helps.

Message.Title: a little too greedy
Message.Msg: they lowered expectations with the 13 to 14 leak, setting up an offer of 15, which might have worked. but trying to force through a 13.65 isn't going to work, when most shareholders paid several $ more.
